unnormalised: Rental Agreements: Are You Covered, Yaar?
normalised: Rental Agreements: Are You Covered, Friend?

unnormalised: Mumbai - Landlords and tenants, listen up! Getting ready to rent that cozy 1 BHK near Dadar, or that spacious 2,000 sq ft apartment in Bandra? Don't skip the rental agreement, boss!
normalised: Mumbai - Landlords and tenants, listen up! Getting ready to rent that cozy one B H K near Dadar, or that spacious two thousand square feet apartment in Bandra? Don't skip the rental agreement, boss!

unnormalised: News is, many folks in Mumbai and Delhi still rely on verbal agreements. Big mistake! A proper, written rental agreement protects both parties, clarifying everything from rent amount (Rs. 25,000? Rs. 50,000?), to maintenance charges, security deposit (usually 2-3 months rent, right?), and even notice periods.
normalised: News is, many folks in Mumbai and Delhi still rely on verbal agreements. Big mistake! A proper, written rental agreement protects both parties, clarifying everything from rent amount (rupees twenty five thousand? rupees fifty thousand?), to maintenance charges, security deposit (usually two to three months rent, right?), and even notice periods.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma, a leading real estate lawyer, advises having a registered agreement to avoid headaches later. Disputes over late rent, damages, or even eviction can be a nightmare without one.
normalised: Doctor Sharma, a leading real estate lawyer, advises having a registered agreement to avoid headaches later. Disputes over late rent, damages, or even eviction can be a nightmare without one.

unnormalised: Think of it like this: A rental agreement is your legal 'setting' with your landlord or tenant. Get it right, and you can celebrate Diwali in peace! Don't risk it; talk to a lawyer or use online platforms for a quick and easy agreement. Avoid kachha agreements at all costs, bhai!
normalised: Think of it like this: A rental agreement is your legal 'setting' with your landlord or tenant. Get it right, and you can celebrate Diwali in peace! Don't risk it; talk to a lawyer or use online platforms for a quick and easy agreement. Avoid kachha agreements at all costs, brother!
